i found this but it use phoenix 5 and not 6 is there something similar just for phoenix 6?found this https://github.com/CrossTheRoadElec/Phoenix6-Examples/tree/main/java/MotionMagic but i dont understand how to use it is there any video for this ?

thanks!

Phoenix 6

Motion Magic® Controls

In addition to basic PID control, the Talon FX also supports onboard motion profiling using Motion Magic® controls. Motion Magic®: Motion Magic® is a control mode that provides the benefit of Motio...

This is the documentation, it’s pretty straightforward.

I found that there’s not really videos explaining FRC specific code, especially at the higher-level.
Your best bet is looking at other teams code on GitHub.

10219Ryba:

I found that there’s not really videos explaining FRC specific code, especially at the higher-level.

Videos (and any unofficial documentation/tutorials) are too liable to fall out of date in my opinion. With how quickly WPILib has been changing over the past few years[1], I don’t think it’s worth trying to make resources in a format that can’t be maintained easily.

  1. A mentor who graduated college this year used commands v1 and SmartDashboard as a student! Those will both have their replacements replaced next year. ↩︎

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":6,"updated_at":"2025-09-30T08:56:16.221Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":90,"readers_count":89,"score":22.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":506675,"topic_slug":"is-there-something-similar-just-for-phoenix-6","display_username":"avraham","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":25454,"username":"Corey_Applegate","name":"Corey Applegate","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/corey_applegate/{size}/250858_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":76458,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/is-there-something-similar-just-for-phoenix-6/506675/5","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3752252,"name":"Corey Applegate","username":"Corey_Applegate","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/corey_applegate/{size}/250858_2.png","created_at":"2025-09-30T13:06:31.687Z","cooked":"

Yep, and now looking at your original post the “this” link is that video just hidden.

I used to be the Code mentor and trainer and alway kept up with these updates. More recently I have been playing the role of mechanical engineer mentor. I wish I had a great grasp on the Phoenix 6 libraries. There are a lot of great tools in there so I could update these videos. It seems CTRE has change the base Motion Magice to MotionMagicVoltage and have added a few other control methods.

The best thing I can share and recommend is how I have and would approach this.

  • Download the CTRE example and run it on a robot subsystem that has no mechanical limits. ( I have used a Drive train Wheel Many times)
  • Get that example running predictably and explore some of the (New to me) gear ratio settings added since the video was made
  • Now add a second motor that is again has not mechanical limits and maybe is isolated from the first.
    • Set it to follow the first
    • Invert its rotation
  • Other great test
    • Use the steer motors of a swerve module for the MM test.
    • Try using the remote sensor
      • I believe there is a parameter to tell the system the gear ratio between the motor and encoder.

I tend to do these steps once a year with at least one team in my area. It both assures me that I’m not steering a program wrong, and we both get to see the process and get confidence in the code. After testing on a safe subsystem, I change the CAN ID’s to the target (Maybe an elevator) and slowly bring up the speed verifying encoders are in phase with motors and Positive encoder counts and Green LED result in logical positive movement.

Unfortunately, CTRE seems to have removed all the data output prints that were used to tune the system but in reality it’s best to use the graphing features of TunerX. I find a lot of the time the base PID values will get things moving, and a few “educated” guests and check updates to P and D and FF will get you close enough, and if you’re looking for a well-tuned PIDF controller well, you likely have the aptitude to collect the data and analyze it. At the end of the day if the game piece consistently goes in the scoring place, then the PIDF control is good and no one will really care if there is still meat on the bone. {Until it misses in the finals}
